UNPRECEDENTED SENIOR WEEK

HOPKINS DOWNS AGGIES

HOPKINS WINS CHAMFIONSHIPS

Orator of the Day Will Be Dr. Gorgas
of Canal Zone Fame—Members
of the Graduating Class.

Interval Between Final Exams and Cornmencement Will Be Memorable for
Boat Ride, Prom, Classday, etc.

Black and Blue Baseball Team Plays
a Good Game at College Park.
Pieper's Good Pitching.

The South Atlantic Intercollegiates Go
to the Varsity Track and Field
Team New Records Made.

Plans for the Senior Week, which
is. to occupy the interval between
the close of the final 'examinations
and commencement, are progressing auspiciously and the committee
that has them in charge is highly
optimistic over the interest that has
been evinced, not only among the
senior class itself, but also by .the
members of the other .classes, who
are lending their heartiest co-operation. .Already assurances of support for the 'proposed boat ride
down the bay that is scheduled for
Friday, June 7, have been given by
the whole undergraduate body. At
class meetings, held for the purpose,'
the three lower classes agreed to
take the equivalent of two tickets a
man at a dollar a• ticket. This assures payment for chartering the
steamer and the seniors undertake
to pay for music and refreshments
for the occasion.
The excursion will be on the
steamboat "Annapolis" of the Tolchester line, and there will be room
for six hundred on board. Tickets
will be offered to graduate and
medical students and to • alumni at
the same price as to undergraduates, and it is hoped that all departments will be well represented.
There is no limit to the number
of tickets that anyone may buy.
Mothers and fathers, brothers and
sisters, friends, sweethearts and
wives will be heartily welcomed.
One of the chief attractions of the
occasion, however, will be in the
fact that it will be strictly a Hopkins affair. Tickets will not be
offered to the general hblic, but
can be secured only from the class
committees and from the Senior
Week committee.
On Thursday evening the senior
prom will be held., and, as usual, will
be a subscription affair. Although
coming during warm weather, these
dances have always been very enjoyable, owing to the informality and
freedom that characterizes them. It
is hoped that the attendance will be
large this year and the plans so far
made by the committee promise an
unusually good _ time for all who
attend. Elaborate souvenirs will be
Dr. Barnett Interviewed.
given each couple. All who expect

Hopkins defeated the Maryland
Agricultural College baseball team
Saturday afternoon at College Park
by the score of 9 to 3. The Black
and Blue nine is making a great
showing against the Maryland college teams, and stands a good
chance of winning the state championship.
Captain Pieper pitched fine ball
against the Aggies, and but for a
combination of errors in the eighth
inning he would have shut them out
completely. As it was, only three
hits were made off of him. Smith,
the Farmers' twirler, struck out
twice as many players as Pieper, but
did not have as good control. The
Hopkins' players touched him up
for twelve hits. Wilson, Hobbs and
Pieper led in the batting. Each made
a three-bagger and two singles, and
Wilson, who came to bat once more
than the other two, also smashed
out a double.
Two runs were scored by Hopkins in the first inning. Another
tally was made in the fourth session, and the game was clinched
with three more runs in the sixth
and two in the seventh innings.
"Judge" Newman,the regular Hopkins catcher, was unable to leave his
work at the medical school to go on
the trip with the team. Ober filled
his place capably, and scored two of
the Hopkins' tallies. Wharton Smith
replaced Ober in center field. The
stmunary:

The first annual meet of the
South Atlantic Intercollegiate Athletic Association resulted in a cleancut victory for the Hopkins team,
which scored 48Y, • points, with a
margin of 20Y, points over the University of North Carolina, who was
the nearest competitor. The scores
of the other members of the Association were as follows: University
of North Carolina, 28; North Carolina A. and M. College, 24; Virginia Polytechnic Institute, 23' 2
Washington and Lee University,
15; Georgetown University, 13,
and Richmond College, o.
The performances show that the
class of athletes sent to the meet by
the institutions of this part of the
country is of the highest order. In
the 440-yard dash Glass, of Washington and Lee, broke the South
Atlantic record of 51/
5 seconds,
first by 3/5 seconds in the trials on
Friday, and then again by another
second in the finals on
Saturday. This was the best piece
of running during the meet. In
the two-mile run Patterson, of
North Carolina, after winning the
mile, lowered the Hopkins' record
to io minutes 63'; seconds. The
Hopkins' records in the half-mile
and discus fell at the same time.
Horrax was the star of the Hopkins team. He won the individual
trophy (a large silver loving cup)
by making 202 points, including
three firsts. The I20-yard hurdles,
the broad jump and the pole vault,
and a second in the discus, besides
a tie for second place in the high
jump. Wagner came next after
Horrax. He won the mo and 120
yard dashes, the mo in IoY5 seconds, and the 220 in 23/
5 seconds.
The 220 was a beautiful race—at
the half-way post Wagner was some
fifteen yards behind Glass, of W.
and Lee, with Eller, of Georgetown,
quiting the race in the rear. Wagner
began a wonderful sprint, and beat
out Glass in the last Too yards by
a comfortable margin. Dignan threw
the shot farther than the other contestants, but even at this he failed
to come up to his usual form. He
also got third in the hammer throw.
Others who scored for the 'varsity
were: Tappan, 3 points; Baldwin,
2 points; Hunter, 2 points;
2 points; Fulton, I point.
After the meet was won by the
'varsity the relay race was run off
as the feature event of the day.
Three teams entered—Washington
and Lee, Georgetown and Hopkins.

Arrangements have been almost
completed for the University Commencement, which is to be held on
June ii. The ceremonies will take
Place in the Academy of Music at
4 P. M. and will be preceded by
the usual parade of faculty and candidates for degrees, from the University building to the theatre.
The address will be made this
year by Dr. William C. Gorgas,
chief health officer of the Canal
Zone at Panama. Dr. Gorgas' work
at Panama has been wonderful, and
the results he has achieved have
made him famous throughout the
Whole medical world.
As far as can be estimated at
present, the number of degrees conferred this year will be in the neighborhood of one hundred and sixty.
The senior class at the Medical
School numbers eighty-five members, or about half of the total number of graduates. Next in numbers
will be the candidates for the degree of bachelor of arts, thirtyseven in all probability. Thirty degrees of doctor of philosophy will
Probably be conferred and the master of arts degree will be bestowed
on ten.
The members of the graduating
class of the undergraduate department are the following: Herman S.
Applebaum, Donald K. Belt, Bertram Benedict, William N. Brown,

The Perfect College Yell.

Authorities hold that the perfect
yell is based on the bray of the
Missouri mule, alternating with the
notes of the game roaster, modified
by the trumpet of the auto horn.
War whoops and the sound of a
couple of kegs of nails falling down
the cellar steps furnish an impressive crescendo, while the most effective farewell is a cross between
the song of a dying calf and a lost
soul. These finer shadings express
the deeper emotions turned loose on
a civilized country.—Baltintore Sun.
Add to these the moans of a
cracked bass viol and the nocturnal
notes of a love-sick tom-cat, and
we think the yell will be a piece of
art.

BALTIMORE, MD., MAY 6, 1912

The Man for the Place.

A BUSINESS SCHOOL

Within the next two weeks a
new president of the Athletic Board
will be elected. The requirements
of the position have at no time been
slight; just at present it might be
well for us to remind ourselves
that they are even more exacting
than is usual.
The changes which the sudden
and rapid growth of Hopkins athletics have made necessary are not
yet thoroughly worked out. Things
are not as yet adjusted. There is
9pportunity for friction. If this
is to be avoided, the new president must be a man of tact. He
must enjoy the confidence of graduates and undergraduates alike.
He must be able to conciliate. He
must be able to look at every question from the standpoint of reason, not of partisanship. Lastly, he
must be firm, energetic, and ready
to speak his mind on a subject
after he has reached a well-considered conclusion. Such a man
will probably not be easy to find;
but the man for the place is never
easy to find. We hope that at the
coming mass-meeting there will be
a large number of candidates who
will offer themselves.

The unprecedented interest which
is being manifested this year in
the ceremonies of graduation and
the likelihood that there will be a
memorable round of festivities to
mark the last week of the present
senior class' college life make the
absence of one familiar landmark
doubly noticeable. There will be
no Hullabaloo!
Two commencements have come
and gone without the issuing of a
class-book by the graduating class.
A third commencement, one which
in all probability will be more festive and more impressive than any
that has yet taken place in the history of Hopkins, will also come and
go, likewise unmarked. Shall this
continue?
The class of 1913 elected a Hullabaloo board last year and this.
year the class of 1914 has followed
suit. If these boards are energetic,
if they put their hearts in the work
which their c!asses have entrusted
to them, the commencements ot tne
next two years will not be without
a permanent record of the doings
of the graduating class.
A class-book is not a thing which
has its greatest value in the years
immediately after we leave college.
It increases in interest as the years
worth
go on. But that it is a thin.6
while has been proved by the experience of several generations of
American college classes.
The Musical Clubs have agreed
to give a concert during the next
few weeks for the benefit of the
two Hullabaloos. They are showing the proper spirit. Let the students do the same, and the two
boards will have no .excuse for discouragement or lethargy.

Mr. Corner's Resolutions.

At the recent mass-meeting called
by the Student Council, Mr. Harry
E. Corner offered a series of resolutions, the intent of which was to
increase undergraduate representation on the Athletic Board. Because of the lateness of the hour,
the resolutions were laid on the
table. During the present week a
general mass-meeting of the Athletic Association will be held for
the purpose of nominating candidates for the approaching election.
This meeting Vill afford a timely
opportunity for the consideration
of the change proposed by Mr.
Corner's resolutions. There has
long been a feeling that undergraduate sentiment is not consistently or adequately reflected in the
athletic policy of the University.
Whether it is, whether it ought to
be, or whether it ever can be so
reflected, are interesting questions,
and ones which should be submitted to the most careful consideration. The whole question ought to
be taken up, threshed out in the
light of reason, and settled once
for all. There should be no feeling on the part of anyone that
the undergraduates are becoming
grasping or unruly or mutinous.
From their ranks come a great
majority of the men who play on
our athletic teams; and if they feel
that they are not having a fair voice
in the conduct of our athletics, the
question ought at once to be opened
up and discussed. We look to the
coming meeting to effect this.

THE NEWS—LETTER, MAY 6, 1912.
THE NEWS-LETTER'S MAIL BAG
A Column in Which the Correspondents
Are Allowed Latitude, but Shoulder the Responsibility.
(THe NEWs-LETTER is always glad to
Publish letters of reasonable length upon
topics of interest in University circles.
Alumni especially are urged to make use
of this column. All communications, as
evidence of good faith, should be .en(lorsed with the name of the writer,
Which, upon request, will be withheld.)
Respectfully Suggested.
To the Editor of THE NEWS-LETTER:

For the majority of the Johns
Hopkins undergraduates, the un-:
dergraduate curriculum is too ambitious. Most men who come to
Hopkins have never been accustomed to read the newspapers. It
is true that they devour the sporting page, but they ignore the general news of the day, and they
would not touch the editorials with
a.ten-foot pole. The serious magazines are both literally and figuratively a closed book to them. The
movements in the political sphere
have never concerned them. They
do not know even the name of the
Governor of New York State or
the. Mayor of New York City.
They are blissfully unaware that a
vast European war was recently
Upon the point of breaking out.
..They do not know what "conservation of natural resources" means.
They have never heard of the International Arbitration movement.
When election day draws near they
are as easily tricked by political
demagogues, as the most uneducated supporters of the "machine."
They despise culture. They laugh at
Poetry. They sneer at the sacred,
and they worship the unclean.
It is such men that Johns Hopkins receives. And so far from
endeavoring to realize their deficiencies and patiently to correct
them, it sets so high a standard
that the undergraduates are merely
hardened in their beliefs. It tries
to make them understand Chaucer,
Shakespeare and Spenser, when
they scoff at the entire institution
of good reading. It tries to inculcate into them Horace, when they
have been used only to George
Barr McCutcheon and The Saturday Evening Post. It asks them
to appreciate the subtle currents,
of Medieval history, when they do
Hot even know of the present split
in the Republican party. It lectures
to them on the history of dead
religions, when they know nothing of modern ones. It tries to
teach them to write good English,
when they would echo, in a literary discussion, the query of the
Pittsburgh millionare : "What are
Keats ?" It tries to instil learning
without first trying to make the
undergraduate want learning. It
tries to build the upper stories,
when there is no foundation.
The first need of the undergraduate department is this foundation.
I would have instituted weekly
lectures on problems of the day, at

which undergraduate attendance
would be compulsory. I would
have the sophomores take the
course in nineteenth century literature instead of fifteenth and sixteenth. (An introductory course
in literature is all well enough, if
the introduction leads to further
acquaintance, but few undergraduates make further use of the hated
introduction which they receive in
English Literature I.) I would
have a course on ,government made
compulsory. Now, I would not
cast aside the higher forms of
knowledge, I would merely have
them prefaced by the lower. And if
I be asked the method by which I
should do this, I would advocate
the English system of a difference
in curriculum between .the. ignorant
and the well-informed undergraduates—either a combination of a
five years' course for the one, and
a four or three years' course for
the other, or entirely, different
courses of study. At all events, the
present system accomplishes nothing. It holds back too much those
who would like to go forward, or
else it pushes forward those who
are not yet ready for the start.
B. B.
April 20, 1912.
NEWS-LETTER:
THE
Editor
of
To the
I read in your number of April
15 your editorial on social aspects
of the future, when you will have
two distinct departments in the academic and engineering schools. Let
me say that I highly commend your
views on this subject of keeping
the students of these departments
from forming any social distinction.
I am sorry to say that at Yale
there is such a distinction, and that
there are such violences and jealousies as you mention between the
students of Yale "Sheff" and Yale
academic. Although the breach between the two departments is not
so great as it has been in the past,
yet this breach is still great enough
to cause considerable unpleasantness.
As I have been a student at Hopkins myself and, therefore, have
great interest in the growth of my
former alma mater, I sincerely hope
that there will never be any such
unfortunate state of affairs in social
matters at Hopkins as there is at
CHARLES H. SIMON.
Yale.

Whatever may be said concerning the absurdity and emptiness of
"rooting," there is no denying that
it helps a team. So long as the man
who feels that he is the object of
trust and admiration is going to do
better work than the man who
thinks that the world has lost confidence in him for his blunders, just
so long rooting is going to help to
win games and races and political
contests. The objection that cheering which is organized is useless because it is artificial and not spontaneous is a foolish one. The necessity for organized cheering and its
excuse are merely this: So long as
a man doesn't know whether or not
any of the other spectators about
him are going to join in the yell that
he wants to let out, he refrains from
making himself conspicuous, and
keeps his emotion pent up. Organized cheering means that everybody
is going to cheer; that nobody is going to be conspicuous, and that the
team will get all the more benefit.
Last Saturday's occurrence was
unfortunate. It lent the impression
—and the impression was a false
one—that the Hopkins spectators
were apathetic. In the critical game
of the year the team' received no
support from the benches. The
cheer leader should take his job
seriously. It is a perfectly honorable position. It is just as much to
a man's credit to be able to lead a
cheer well as it is to drive a nail
well or to write a letter well, or to
run a race well. There are only
going to be two more games at
Homewood this spring. Let us hope
that the cheer leader will be on the
STENTOR.
job.

buttery, and had to be eaten standing, or taken to the student's room.
Dinner was the only really "square
meal" of the day.

Take Northern Trip.

A committee, consisting of Mr.
R. Brent Keyser and Professors
William Bullock Clark and Joseph
Sweetman Ames, left last Monday
for a trip to the technical schools
of the North. They returned on
Thursday. The object the the trip
was to consult the directors of the
northern institutions as to the curriculum of the new technical
school and the selection of a faculty. Among those consulted were:
Director Chittenden of Sheffield
Scientific School, President Maclaurin of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, President Lowell of Harvard, and Dean Sabine
of the Harvard Technical School.

HOPKINS DOWNS OLD RIVALS
First Tennis Match on New Homewood
Courts a Victory Over St. John's
By 4 to 3.

The
arsity tennis team played
the first match of the season at
Homewood last Wednesday. Most
of the matches were played on the
new grass courts, which were then
in use for the first time. The contest was with St. John's. After a
hard struggle Hopkins won, 4 to
3, after playing an extra match
to decide the tie. The winning
doubles-team of the two colleges
played the determining match. Unfortunately for St. John's, their
team had to play two more sets
than their opponents, so they were
quite decisively beaten.

HOPKINS WINS CHAMFIONSHIPS

Orator of the Day Will Be Dr. Gorgas
of Canal Zone Fame—Members
of the Graduating Class.

Interval Between Final Exams and Cornmencement Will Be Memorable for
Boat Ride, Prom, Classday, etc.

Plans for the Senior Week, which
is. to occupy the interval between
the close of the final 'examinations
and commencement, are progressing auspiciously and the committee
that has them in charge is highly
optimistic over the interest that has
been evinced, not only among the
senior class itself, but also by .the
members of the other .classes, who
are lending their heartiest co-operation. .Already assurances of support for the 'proposed boat ride
down the bay that is scheduled for
Friday, June 7, have been given by
the whole undergraduate body. At
class meetings, held for the purpose,'
the three lower classes agreed to
take the equivalent of two tickets a
man at a dollar a• ticket. This assures payment for chartering the
steamer and the seniors undertake
to pay for music and refreshments
for the occasion.
The excursion will be on the
steamboat "Annapolis" of the Tolchester line, and there will be room
for six hundred on board. Tickets
will be offered to graduate and
medical students and to • alumni at
the same price as to undergraduates, and it is hoped that all departments will be well represented.
There is no limit to the number
of tickets that anyone may buy.
Mothers and fathers, brothers and
sisters, friends, sweethearts and
wives will be heartily welcomed.
One of the chief attractions of the
occasion, however, will be in the
fact that it will be strictly a Hopkins affair. Tickets will not be
offered to the general hblic, but
can be secured only from the class
committees and from the Senior
Week committee.
On Thursday evening the senior
prom will be held., and, as usual, will
be a subscription affair. Although
coming during warm weather, these
dances have always been very enjoyable, owing to the informality and
freedom that characterizes them. It
is hoped that the attendance will be
large this year and the plans so far
made by the committee promise an
unusually good _ time for all who
attend. Elaborate souvenirs will be

Hopkins defeated the Maryland
Agricultural College baseball team
Saturday afternoon at College Park
by the score of 9 to 3. The Black
and Blue nine is making a great
showing against the Maryland college teams, and stands a good
chance of winning the state championship.
Captain Pieper pitched fine ball
against the Aggies, and but for a
combination of errors in the eighth
inning he would have shut them out
completely. As it was, only three
hits were made off of him. Smith,
the Farmers' twirler, struck out
twice as many players as Pieper, but
did not have as good control. The
Hopkins' players touched him up
for twelve hits. Wilson, Hobbs and
Pieper led in the batting. Each made
a three-bagger and two singles, and
Wilson, who came to bat once more
than the other two, also smashed
out a double.
Two runs were scored by Hopkins in the first inning. Another
tally was made in the fourth session, and the game was clinched
with three more runs in the sixth
and two in the seventh innings.
"Judge" Newman,the regular Hopkins catcher, was unable to leave his
work at the medical school to go on
the trip with the team. Ober filled
his place capably, and scored two of
the Hopkins' tallies. Wharton Smith
replaced Ober in center field. The
stmunary:

The first annual meet of the
South Atlantic Intercollegiate Athletic Association resulted in a cleancut victory for the Hopkins team,
which scored 48Y, • points, with a
margin of 20Y, points over the University of North Carolina, who was
the nearest competitor. The scores
of the other members of the Association were as follows: University
of North Carolina, 28; North Carolina A. and M. College, 24; Virginia Polytechnic Institute, 23' 2
Washington and Lee University,
15; Georgetown University, 13,
and Richmond College, o.
The performances show that the
class of athletes sent to the meet by
the institutions of this part of the
country is of the highest order. In
the 440-yard dash Glass, of Washington and Lee, broke the South
Atlantic record of 51/
5 seconds,
first by 3/5 seconds in the trials on
Friday, and then again by another
second in the finals on
Saturday. This was the best piece
of running during the meet. In
the two-mile run Patterson, of
North Carolina, after winning the
mile, lowered the Hopkins' record
to io minutes 63'; seconds. The
Hopkins' records in the half-mile
and discus fell at the same time.
Horrax was the star of the Hopkins team. He won the individual
trophy (a large silver loving cup)
by making 202 points, including
three firsts. The I20-yard hurdles,
the broad jump and the pole vault,
and a second in the discus, besides
a tie for second place in the high
jump. Wagner came next after
Horrax. He won the mo and 120
yard dashes, the mo in IoY5 seconds, and the 220 in 23/
5 seconds.
The 220 was a beautiful race—at
the half-way post Wagner was some
fifteen yards behind Glass, of W.
and Lee, with Eller, of Georgetown,
quiting the race in the rear. Wagner
began a wonderful sprint, and beat
out Glass in the last Too yards by
a comfortable margin. Dignan threw
the shot farther than the other contestants, but even at this he failed
to come up to his usual form. He
also got third in the hammer throw.
Others who scored for the 'varsity
were: Tappan, 3 points; Baldwin,
2 points; Hunter, 2 points;
2 points; Fulton, I point.
After the meet was won by the
'varsity the relay race was run off
as the feature event of the day.
Three teams entered—Washington
and Lee, Georgetown and Hopkins.

Arrangements have been almost
completed for the University Commencement, which is to be held on
June ii. The ceremonies will take
Place in the Academy of Music at
4 P. M. and will be preceded by
the usual parade of faculty and candidates for degrees, from the University building to the theatre.
The address will be made this
year by Dr. William C. Gorgas,
chief health officer of the Canal
Zone at Panama. Dr. Gorgas' work
at Panama has been wonderful, and
the results he has achieved have
made him famous throughout the
Whole medical world.
As far as can be estimated at
present, the number of degrees conferred this year will be in the neighborhood of one hundred and sixty.
The senior class at the Medical
School numbers eighty-five members, or about half of the total number of graduates. Next in numbers
will be the candidates for the degree of bachelor of arts, thirtyseven in all probability. Thirty degrees of doctor of philosophy will
Probably be conferred and the master of arts degree will be bestowed
on ten.
The members of the graduating
class of the undergraduate department are the following: Herman S.
Applebaum, Donald K. Belt, Bertram Benedict, William N. Brown,
Leslie H. Buckler, John K. Burgan,
John D. Carroll, Maurice H. Coblentz, Harry.N. Cole, James J. Corner, Harry S. Dickey, Hamilton G.

Schmeisser, Hyland P. Stewart, Jr.,
Alan C. Sutton, G. Peter Thomas,
Gabriel H. Todes, H. Milton Wagner, William 0. Weyforth and

The Perfect College Yell.

Authorities hold that the perfect
yell is based on the bray of the
Missouri mule, alternating with the
notes of the game roaster, modified
by the trumpet of the auto horn.
War whoops and the sound of a
couple of kegs of nails falling down
the cellar steps furnish an impressive crescendo, while the most effective farewell is a cross between
the song of a dying calf and a lost
soul. These finer shadings express
the deeper emotions turned loose on
a civilized country.—Baltintore Sun.
Add to these the moans of a
cracked bass viol and the nocturnal
notes of a love-sick tom-cat, and
we think the yell will be a piece of
art.

The Man for the Place.

A BUSINESS SCHOOL

Within the next two weeks a
new president of the Athletic Board
will be elected. The requirements
of the position have at no time been
slight; just at present it might be
well for us to remind ourselves
that they are even more exacting
than is usual.
The changes which the sudden
and rapid growth of Hopkins athletics have made necessary are not
yet thoroughly worked out. Things
are not as yet adjusted. There is
9pportunity for friction. If this
is to be avoided, the new president must be a man of tact. He
must enjoy the confidence of graduates and undergraduates alike.
He must be able to conciliate. He
must be able to look at every question from the standpoint of reason, not of partisanship. Lastly, he
must be firm, energetic, and ready
to speak his mind on a subject
after he has reached a well-considered conclusion. Such a man
will probably not be easy to find;
but the man for the place is never
easy to find. We hope that at the
coming mass-meeting there will be
a large number of candidates who
will offer themselves.

Hullabaloo!

The unprecedented interest which
is being manifested this year in
the ceremonies of graduation and
the likelihood that there will be a
memorable round of festivities to
mark the last week of the present
senior class' college life make the
absence of one familiar landmark
doubly noticeable. There will be
no Hullabaloo!
Two commencements have come
and gone without the issuing of a
class-book by the graduating class.
A third commencement, one which
in all probability will be more festive and more impressive than any
that has yet taken place in the history of Hopkins, will also come and
go, likewise unmarked. Shall this
continue?
The class of 1913 elected a Hullabaloo board last year and this.
year the class of 1914 has followed
suit. If these boards are energetic,
if they put their hearts in the work
which their c!asses have entrusted
to them, the commencements ot tne
next two years will not be without
a permanent record of the doings
of the graduating class.
A class-book is not a thing which
has its greatest value in the years
immediately after we leave college.
It increases in interest as the years
worth
go on. But that it is a thin.6
while has been proved by the experience of several generations of
American college classes.
The Musical Clubs have agreed
to give a concert during the next
few weeks for the benefit of the
two Hullabaloos. They are showing the proper spirit. Let the students do the same, and the two
boards will have no .excuse for discouragement or lethargy.

Mr. Corner's Resolutions.

At the recent mass-meeting called
by the Student Council, Mr. Harry
E. Corner offered a series of resolutions, the intent of which was to
increase undergraduate representation on the Athletic Board. Because of the lateness of the hour,
the resolutions were laid on the
table. During the present week a
general mass-meeting of the Athletic Association will be held for
the purpose of nominating candidates for the approaching election.
This meeting Vill afford a timely
opportunity for the consideration
of the change proposed by Mr.
Corner's resolutions. There has
long been a feeling that undergraduate sentiment is not consistently or adequately reflected in the
athletic policy of the University.
Whether it is, whether it ought to
be, or whether it ever can be so
reflected, are interesting questions,
and ones which should be submitted to the most careful consideration. The whole question ought to
be taken up, threshed out in the
light of reason, and settled once
for all. There should be no feeling on the part of anyone that
the undergraduates are becoming
grasping or unruly or mutinous.
From their ranks come a great
majority of the men who play on
our athletic teams; and if they feel
that they are not having a fair voice
in the conduct of our athletics, the
question ought at once to be opened
up and discussed. We look to the
coming meeting to effect this.

THE NEWS—LETTER, MAY 6, 1912.
THE NEWS-LETTER'S MAIL BAG
A Column in Which the Correspondents
Are Allowed Latitude, but Shoulder the Responsibility.
(THe NEWs-LETTER is always glad to
Publish letters of reasonable length upon
topics of interest in University circles.
Alumni especially are urged to make use
of this column. All communications, as
evidence of good faith, should be .en(lorsed with the name of the writer,
Which, upon request, will be withheld.)
Respectfully Suggested.
To the Editor of THE NEWS-LETTER:

For the majority of the Johns
Hopkins undergraduates, the un-:
dergraduate curriculum is too ambitious. Most men who come to
Hopkins have never been accustomed to read the newspapers. It
is true that they devour the sporting page, but they ignore the general news of the day, and they
would not touch the editorials with
a.ten-foot pole. The serious magazines are both literally and figuratively a closed book to them. The
movements in the political sphere
have never concerned them. They
do not know even the name of the
Governor of New York State or
the. Mayor of New York City.
They are blissfully unaware that a
vast European war was recently
Upon the point of breaking out.
..They do not know what "conservation of natural resources" means.
They have never heard of the International Arbitration movement.
When election day draws near they
are as easily tricked by political
demagogues, as the most uneducated supporters of the "machine."
They despise culture. They laugh at
Poetry. They sneer at the sacred,
and they worship the unclean.
It is such men that Johns Hopkins receives. And so far from
endeavoring to realize their deficiencies and patiently to correct
them, it sets so high a standard
that the undergraduates are merely
hardened in their beliefs. It tries
to make them understand Chaucer,
Shakespeare and Spenser, when
they scoff at the entire institution
of good reading. It tries to inculcate into them Horace, when they
have been used only to George
Barr McCutcheon and The Saturday Evening Post. It asks them
to appreciate the subtle currents,
of Medieval history, when they do
Hot even know of the present split
in the Republican party. It lectures
to them on the history of dead
religions, when they know nothing of modern ones. It tries to
teach them to write good English,
when they would echo, in a literary discussion, the query of the
Pittsburgh millionare : "What are
Keats ?" It tries to instil learning
without first trying to make the
undergraduate want learning. It
tries to build the upper stories,
when there is no foundation.
The first need of the undergraduate department is this foundation.
I would have instituted weekly
lectures on problems of the day, at

which undergraduate attendance
would be compulsory. I would
have the sophomores take the
course in nineteenth century literature instead of fifteenth and sixteenth. (An introductory course
in literature is all well enough, if
the introduction leads to further
acquaintance, but few undergraduates make further use of the hated
introduction which they receive in
English Literature I.) I would
have a course on ,government made
compulsory. Now, I would not
cast aside the higher forms of
knowledge, I would merely have
them prefaced by the lower. And if
I be asked the method by which I
should do this, I would advocate
the English system of a difference
in curriculum between .the. ignorant
and the well-informed undergraduates—either a combination of a
five years' course for the one, and
a four or three years' course for
the other, or entirely, different
courses of study. At all events, the
present system accomplishes nothing. It holds back too much those
who would like to go forward, or
else it pushes forward those who
are not yet ready for the start.
B. B.
April 20, 1912.
NEWS-LETTER:
THE
Editor
of
To the
I read in your number of April
15 your editorial on social aspects
of the future, when you will have
two distinct departments in the academic and engineering schools. Let
me say that I highly commend your
views on this subject of keeping
the students of these departments
from forming any social distinction.
I am sorry to say that at Yale
there is such a distinction, and that
there are such violences and jealousies as you mention between the
students of Yale "Sheff" and Yale
academic. Although the breach between the two departments is not
so great as it has been in the past,
yet this breach is still great enough
to cause considerable unpleasantness.
As I have been a student at Hopkins myself and, therefore, have
great interest in the growth of my
former alma mater, I sincerely hope
that there will never be any such
unfortunate state of affairs in social
matters at Hopkins as there is at
CHARLES H. SIMON.
Yale.

Whatever may be said concerning the absurdity and emptiness of
"rooting," there is no denying that
it helps a team. So long as the man
who feels that he is the object of
trust and admiration is going to do
better work than the man who
thinks that the world has lost confidence in him for his blunders, just
so long rooting is going to help to
win games and races and political
contests. The objection that cheering which is organized is useless because it is artificial and not spontaneous is a foolish one. The necessity for organized cheering and its
excuse are merely this: So long as
a man doesn't know whether or not
any of the other spectators about
him are going to join in the yell that
he wants to let out, he refrains from
making himself conspicuous, and
keeps his emotion pent up. Organized cheering means that everybody
is going to cheer; that nobody is going to be conspicuous, and that the
team will get all the more benefit.
Last Saturday's occurrence was
unfortunate. It lent the impression
—and the impression was a false
one—that the Hopkins spectators
were apathetic. In the critical game
of the year the team' received no
support from the benches. The
cheer leader should take his job
seriously. It is a perfectly honorable position. It is just as much to
a man's credit to be able to lead a
cheer well as it is to drive a nail
well or to write a letter well, or to
run a race well. There are only
going to be two more games at
Homewood this spring. Let us hope
that the cheer leader will be on the

Dinner was the only really "square
meal" of the day.

Take Northern Trip.

A committee, consisting of Mr.
R. Brent Keyser and Professors
William Bullock Clark and Joseph
Sweetman Ames, left last Monday
for a trip to the technical schools
of the North. They returned on
Thursday. The object the the trip
was to consult the directors of the
northern institutions as to the curriculum of the new technical
school and the selection of a faculty. Among those consulted were:
Director Chittenden of Sheffield
Scientific School, President Maclaurin of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, President Lowell of Harvard, and Dean Sabine
of the Harvard Technical School.

HOPKINS DOWNS OLD RIVALS
First Tennis Match on New Homewood
Courts a Victory Over St. John's
By 4 to 3.

The
arsity tennis team played
the first match of the season at
Homewood last Wednesday. Most
of the matches were played on the
new grass courts, which were then
in use for the first time. The contest was with St. John's. After a
hard struggle Hopkins won, 4 to
3, after playing an extra match
to decide the tie. The winning
doubles-team of the two colleges
played the determining match. Unfortunately for St. John's, their
team had to play two more sets
than their opponents, so they were
quite decisively beaten.
